article.description:
A little pregame psychology by Xavier coach
Thad Matta and a second-half challenge to his team combined to give
the Musketeers (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today; No. 21 Associated Press) just enough to hold off Siena 96-88
Monday night.
article.headline: Matta gets Musketeers shooting, playing defense

images.name: West_David 021223 inline
images.caption: Xavier's David West, left, squeezes past Siena's Brent Sniezyk on his way to 21 points.

article.linkText: Coach's talk does the trick twice for No. 20 Xavier
article.story: ALBANY, N.Y. (AP) -- A little pregame psychology by Xavier coach Thad Matta and a second-half challenge to his team combined to give the Musketeers (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today; No. 21 Associated Press) just enough to hold off Siena 96-88 Monday night. ''We haven't been shooting the ball real well, so I was going psychological warfare with our guys,'' Matta said. ''I was telling them, 'This is a shooter's gym. This is a gym that as a pure shooter you love to play in' and all this stuff.'' Matta admitted later he knew nothing of the sort about Albany's Pepsi Arena, but his team was in need of a good shooting performance. And he got it against Siena, as the Musketeers hit just less than 50 percent from the field (29-for-60) and were 10-for-22 from 3-point range. So much for the carrot. Matta's stick came midway through the second half with Xavier clinging to a one-point lead and the Musketeers in a huddle on the sideline. ''I challenged them a little bit from the defensive side of the ball,'' Matta said. ''Offense wasn't a problem for us. ... I just kind of went at them. I told them I didn't care if we ever shot the ball again. I wanted to see us get some stops.'' Xavier guard Lionel Chalmers said the Musketeers (7-2) needed the prodding. ''He got us going, basically. He got on us. Everybody could see we weren't doing it,'' Chalmers said. Xavier made three consecutive defensive stops and, thanks Romain Sato's 3-pointer with 2:20 to play with the Musketeers clinging to a 86-83 lead, Xavier had just enough to stave off Siena. Sato, a junior from Central African Republic, finished with 33 points. He was 6-for-12 from 3-point range, despite entering the game shooting 19.6 percent (11-for-56) from beyond the arc. ''Tonight I played good,'' Sato said. ''I felt good about my shot. ... Sometimes you shoot the ball well and sometimes you don't.'' Two-time Atlantic 10 player of the year David West, contending all night with double teams or collapsing zone defenses, had 21 points, a game-high 13 rebounds and a team-high six assists for the Musketeers. Xavier was up 50-42 at halftime and led the entire second half. On the three occasions Siena closed to a point, West or Sato was there with a big shot. Trailing 84-76, Siena made its final charge with a 7-2 run behind a three-point play from Michael Haddix, a low-post basket by Haddix around West and Prosper Karangwa's layup. Sato then buried his 3-pointer from the top of the key to thwart the Saints (5-3). He narrowly missed bettering his career high for points, 34, set last season against George Washington. ''I think the best thing that we take away from the game is that our guys are genuinely disappointed we lost the game,'' Siena coach Rob Lanier said. ''It's a good step. ... The effort and the intensity that we showed tonight is indicative of the potential of this team.'' Chalmers, a former Albany-area high school star, scored 16 points for Xavier despite second-half foul trouble. Haddix had 21 points and five rebounds for Siena, while Karangwa, who fouled out late, had 17 points and team-high totals of eight rebounds and seven assists. Xavier went on a 16-4 run over the final 4:15 of the first half. Sato hit three consecutive 3-pointers, Chalmers had two free throws, West scored on a three-point play down low and Chalmers punctuated the half with a steal and jam over Siena's Tommy Mitchell with 44 seconds to go. Xavier, shooting 74 percent for the season from the foul line, was 10-for-10 from the line in the first half and 13-for-14 over the final 6:50.
